plist.p: Good morning. My name is Steve, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Q4 Anadarko Petroleum Corporation Earnings Conference Call.
And I'll turn the conference over to John Colglazier. Please go ahead, sir.
Thank you, Steve. Good morning, everyone. So glad you could join us today for Anadarko's fourth quarter and full year 2012 conference call.

Today's presentation includes forward-looking statements and certain non-GAAP financial measures, So we encourage you to read the full disclosure and GAAP reconciliations located on our website and attached to last night's earnings release. Also on our website, we provide a comprehensive summary of the company's operations activities in our operations report.

In a moment, we'll turn the call over to Al Walker, who will discuss the company's 2012 results. And Al is joined by other members of our executive team, who will be available to answer the questions later in the call. Al?
Thanks, John, and good morning.

2012 for Anadarko was, in a word, outstanding. First, we delivered record sales volumes of 268 million BOE, well above the high end of our initial guidance. Second, we replaced 162% of our reserves at a cost of less than $15 per BOE before the impact of price revisions.

Third, we achieved a 67% success rate from our deepwater exploration and appraisal program. Fourth, we monetized more than $1 billion of assets and established a market value of more than $6.5 billion for Anadarko's remaining 91% interest in WGP following its IPO. And fifth, we generated $852 million of adjusted free cash flow during the year.
Our record sales volumes growth was driven by our capital-efficient use of (2:22) onshore assets growing at 16% over 2011 with 25,000 barrels per day increase in this higher-margin liquids volumes.

The Wattenberg field in Colorado was the single largest contributor to this growth, increasing liquids sales volumes by 11,000 barrels per day over 2011 – total production of 18,000 barrels or 18,000 BOE per day, which generated rates of return in excess of 100%. This past year, we increased our net resource estimate in this field to 1 billion BOE to 1.5 billion BOE, and doubled the number of identified drill sites to 4,000.

To the south of our core Wattenberg acreage, we closed a $114 million transaction for 59,000 acres, retaining a 20% royalty interest on our fee acreage, and believe by doing this, we have accelerated the value of these assets by using third-party capital.

Beyond Wattenberg, we achieved record sales volumes in many other growth areas of our portfolio. These include the Eagle Ford Shale, our East Texas horizontal liquids plays, the various Permian oil-prone horizons we are actively developing, our Greater Natural Buttes acreage, and the Marcellus Shale.

We have also continued to significantly improve drilling efficiencies across all our active areas. In the Eagle Ford, for example, we exited the year with our drilling cycle times reduced to an average of 9.2 days, giving us a 26% year-over-year improvement.

Complementing the success of our onshore programs in 2012 was one of the most active years in history for our Deepwater international exploration and development teams; that included a resurgence in the activity in the Gulf of Mexico.

Earlier in 2012, we achieved first oil at Caesar/Tonga, and we're currently in the process of completing a fourth development well in the field. We also continued to make significant progress at the Lucius development, our next major megaproject in the Gulf, where the construction of the Lucius Spar is on schedule, and our first development well, as you saw in our release, encountered 910 feet of oil pay, exceeding what we have seen in the unit to date.

During 2012, we promoted a portion of our interest in Lucius by closing a carried interest agreement with a new partner. This transaction should fully fund our capital through first production, significantly increases our project returns, and values our interest in Lucius at almost $2.8 billion, where we have very little amount of capital invested.

We've also advanced the Heidelberg project to first oil, we believe, in 2016, awarding long lead items, taking a design-and-build-to approach, constructing another truss spar with capacity similar to Lucius at 80,000 barrels of oil per day. And we continue to be very active in the Gulf of Mexico, with high-impact exploration, appraisal and development operations ongoing at eight locations.

Turning to our international activities, and starting with Algeria. We expect to achieve first oil production this quarter from the first of three facilities at El Merk, and steadily increase sales volumes throughout 2013 as this new facility ramps towards capacity. We remain committed to Algeria, our partnership with Sonatrach, and our operations there. As I am sure you can expect, we have taken appropriate action with Sonatrach and the Algerian government to enhance security for our people and facilities. We will refrain from discussing our activities on any specific – regarding security at this time, and hope you will understand.

So if I could, let me move on East Africa. Mozambique continues to be an incredible success story. Our discoveries at Golfinho and Atum double the recoverable resource estimate of our offshore Area 1 Block to a range of 35 to 65 Tcf. The projected timeline for the first LNG cargoes remains in 2018 as we've awarded competitive FEED contracts and reached a Heads of Agreement with Eni concerning development of one of our fields.

In West Africa, our partnership submitted a plan of development to the Ghanaian government for the TEN complex. TEN will be the second FPSO development offshore Ghana following Jubilee, which is now producing more than 110,000 barrels of oil per day. We expect 2013 to be another very active year in our international drilling program with a significant number of high-impact exploration wells.

All of the E&P activities we described today provide confidence in our ability to achieve our goal of 3 billion barrels of reserves by the end of 2013. In 2012, we added reserves at competitive costs of $14.65 per BOE, excluding the impact of price revisions. Our proved developed reserves now comprise 74% of our year-end total, an improvement over the previous year's 71%.
Natural-gas prices decreased by about 31% on average for the year, yet only about 2.5% of our reserves were impacted, almost all of which would return at today's strip prices.

In 2012, we also followed through on our commitment to further strengthen the balance sheet. This was driven by our free cash flow and cash received from the successful Algeria tax resolution. By year-end, we repaid all of our borrowings under our $5 billion revolving credit facility, reducing our net-debt-to-cap ratio to 34% from 41%, and we ended the year with $2.5 billion of cash on hand.

As we wrap up today's prepared remarks, I want to thank our employees and contractors for the exceptionally strong operating, exploration, and financial results we delivered for our shareholders again in 2012.
Operator, if you would, let's open it up for questions.
. Your first question comes from the line of Brian Singer with Goldman Sachs. Your line is now open.
Thank you, good morning.
Good morning, Brian.

Couple of questions on Lucius. When we look at the 910 feet of oil pay there, how is that divided between the Pliocene and Miocene sections? And what does it suggest from a resource-potential perspective, both for Lucius and maybe on a risk basis for Phobos?

Brian, I think there is no doubt that we couldn't be anything more than just delighted and tickled with how that well has drilled out. I'm going to let – if you don't mind, I'm going to have Doug give a little more color on that.

But at the same time, I'm not really sure if there is any takeaways for Phobos. I'll probably let Bob Daniels answer that, if you don't mind. And if I can, just leave you the impression – I think we're all very excited. We think it means probably lots of good things for us, but it may be a little early to start trying to give additional estimates.
So with that, if I can, let me turn it over to Doug on the Lucius, and then turn it back to Bob Daniels for the Phobos question.
Sure. Thanks, Al.
Brian, you're right. We're very excited about Lucius. What we found in the Pliocene and Miocene sands there is very encouraging and exciting. The project is on schedule, on budget.

And at this point in time, we have not broken out to split. What we can tell you, though, is just to reiterate the guidance that we see the field as a 300-million-barrel-plus development, and we're extremely excited about the options that the Miocene could add to the development planning.

Yeah, Brian, on the Phobos question, we never really had a big concern about sand content in the Pliocene and Miocene down at Phobos. We've got a lot of confidence that we'll see a lot of sand down there.
It's really – the risk down there is whether it's going to be charged coming out through the Hadrian complex into Phobos. So we'll just have to wait and see on that.
But remember at Phobos too, we've got a deeper objective also – the lower Wilcox that – or the lower tertiary Wilcox that we've got to get down to.

Great, great. Thanks. And then separately, when you think about your mix of associated gas, Marcellus gas, and other dry gas, recognizing you haven't put out guidance. But can you talk about your outlook for gas production trajectory? Does the associated gas in Marcellus win out, or should we expect overall gas volumes to fall going forward?

Brian, it's generally – our expectation is that our gas production will be relatively flat. Time to time, it will be up a little bit, primarily driven by the outstanding results that we've seen in the Marcellus. It's offset by the declines we see in some of our mature fields like IHUB and our base fields onshore.
And Brian, this is Al. We'll give you more color in a couple of weeks, but our plans are just to maintain the four rigs that we have operated there now. We're not taking it down and not taking up.
But I don't think you should expect the industry, likely in this price environment, is going to do a lot with dry gas. But the one dry gas basin that does have economics is the Marcellus.
Thank you.
Your next question comes from the line of Subash Chandra with Jefferies. Your line is now open.

Yeah, thanks. Good morning. My first question on the domestic property. I was curious – some of these huge growers sequentially – Wattenberg and the wet Haynesville – sort of what can we see, sustainably on a quarterly basis? And what are sort of the limitations on growth here in the intermediate term, if any?

Subash, this is Chuck. Everywhere we're putting capital, we're seeing outstanding growth. And we're particularly focused on the liquids activity in the Wattenberg, Maverick, West Texas, and East Texas. That's where most of our capital is going, and we continue to see growth.

We'll give you guidance in February where we're headed with regard to the company growth rate. But I think that the types of trajectories that you've seen in those assets, in particular, if you look back through the operating reports, are the kind of trajectory you would envision in the future. Because that's the kind of investment we're putting in there. The quality of the investments continue to be outstanding. And the growth rates, particularly on the liquid side, have just been remarkable.
And our whole expectation here is to deliver very high returns on our drilling programs, and I think that's what we're doing.

Yeah, I would like to add to – the fact that in addition to the way we're looking at it from an upstream perspective, we also tried to marry that with the midstream. And that's why you've seen us do what we've done in the Rockies, with both Front Range Express and Texas Express. And then the plant that we're bringing on in the – down in the Eagle Ford area mid-year.

So our belief is, as we turn from 2013 into 2014, to reach that 3 billion barrels of proved reserves target we have out there for the end of 2014, that these midstream developments that we have been spending money on will actually feed a lot of growth, both from a production and a reserve standpoint, onshore, which will always, I think in the near-term, be heavily dependent upon the success that we see both at Wattenberg and the Eagle Ford.

Okay, thanks. And a follow-up here on – so maybe on monetizations this year. Maybe you'll talk to this in your 2013 guidance, but if you can comment on it now. Other than Mozambique, are there any other big projects – for instance, I think Tullow talked about selling down TEN. Is that in the cards for instance for you guys? And if you can confirm whether TEN is somewhere around a $5 billion project?

Well, it probably is best – if I can, I'm going to give you my views here, but the better views probably need to come from Bob Gwin. But I think – because we only have a small interest at TEN, it's very different for us than it is for Kosmos. And even though they have the same amount, as well as Tullow.

But as it relates to that particular development, I think we are encouraged by what we're seeing with the way the government's reacted to the plan of development, and I don't believe, Doug, we have any plans at all, in terms of selling down there.

No, that's correct, Al. We're very encouraged and working with the partnership and the Ghanian government with the advancement of the TEN plan. At present, we don't see any direction that we would pursue that would involve selling down there. So we're not going to really speculate on what Tullow plans to do.

But we are encouraged by it. We have targeted production in 2016. And so looking forward to moving that project forward. And we see that that capital range, rough estimate, is approximate to what we see that development to cost.
I think, beyond that, Bob -- following up on monetization.
On monetization, I'd say the other asset to keep an eye on is Brazil.

As you know, early last year we had identified Brazil for divesture. Soon thereafter, around the time we had our Investor Conference last year, there was discussion of ANP proposing a potential unitization between the Itaipu Block and the Whale Park Complex to the northwest. So we put our process on hold.

Given that that unitization process has taken a little while thus far and we want to go ahead and move forward, we've decided recently that we'll get Brazil back on the market, and see if we can work some kind of a structure, such that any redeterminations around the unitization might be able to be adjusted pro forma sale.

The timing of that is difficult. We're obviously targeting 2013, but there are regulatory approvals, et cetera, as we saw with the Devon/BP transaction previously, that cause us to think that would probably be later in the year, before it was actually closed.

Subash, I'm sure there are other companies that do a good job actively monetizing and bringing forward value, but we've got to be at the top of anyone's list, if you go back to 2006 and the way we've done that.

And just last year, looking at what we did with the OCI sale, as well as what we did in the non-core area outside of Wattenberg, what we've done with promoting down Lucius -- and my guess is you'll hear more about that in a few weeks when we talk about Heidelberg.
I think you can continue to expect that we will be active in the management of our assets and trying wherever we can to accelerate value.
Okay. Congrats and thank you.
You bet.
Your next question comes from the line of David Tameron with Wells Fargo. Your line is now open.
Thanks. I cut out there, Al, so I don't know if you said anything particularly relates to Mozambique. But can you just recap where you're at in the monetization process?

Sure. We're looking to sell down 10% working interest, going from 36.5% to 26.5%. We're in the process of marketing that with someone else who is also selling 10%, and our hope is that we'll have something in the coming months to discuss with you in more detail. But our view there is simply, if we can find the right consideration with the right terms and conditions, we would be interested in trying to reduce our interest to 26.5% from 36.5%.
Okay. Any – you said it's ongoing – any -- you guys have any back-end timeframe, as far as when you want to get this done by?
No, I will let Bob describe that, if I can. It'd probably be best to let Bob do that.

Yeah, the only thing I would add is that we've talked in the past, and it remains accurate today, that we would like to do so around the time of FID, which we talked about being around the time at the end of this year. So as we move forward, it's a matter of getting into – getting deeper into the process, finding the right partner, and then as FID comes together, we would expect it to be in place by then.

And, Dave, as you might imagine, we get a lot of inbound interest, and I think our view was to finally formalize the process, invite some people in that we felt could, in fact, be good partners for us for, in some cases, different reasons. And we just started that here at the beginning of January. So we're kind of early into what I would call a quiet marketing of that 10%.

Okay, thanks. And then Barracuda and then Black Pearl, can you talk about how we should view that and how that changes your focus going forward? Do you just now move back North and concentrate on that area? Could you give us some more color around that?

Yeah, David, this is Bob. We drilled those two down there to see whether or not the liquid potential that we had thought could exist down there was actually real. And both of those wells were unsuccessful. We found really good sands. We found a lot of good things down in that area, but obviously, these two didn't work. We've got a lot of information now that's new to us, so we got to roll into our interpretations and see what it means to us going forward.

We have moved back to the North and anticipate the rest of the activity this year will be focused on the North, where we are at Tubarao now, drilling an appraisal well. We've got some exploratory work to do even farther to the north, some prospects that we've talked about before.

And so we've got an active program, but any time we invest that kind of capital and get that information, we need to roll it into our interpretations and see what it all means. We're very disappointed with what we found at this point, but we'll see what it tells us going forward.

Okay. And then last question. Brian, I guess, attempted to ask the question, but any guidance you want to give us for -- I realize February 20, you're doing the Analyst Day or a Conference Call. But can you give us any guidance around any change out from prior years, as far as staying within cash flow – similar-type metrics or similar-type targets and goals for Anadarko? Any color you can give us on 2013?
There is really little that we'd like to share this morning. We'll be sharing it obviously in detail in two weeks.

But I think the prior calls -- we've made the comment that we would expect to see a moderate improvement in our level of spending. And we would certainly expect to still spend within cash flow. Thankfully, the assets that we have are pretty robust from a cash-generating capability, due to the Brent-linked focus on oil and the cost controls that we've had in place.

So we feel we'll be able to increase the budget, stay within cash flow, and continue to improve the balance sheet as we bring in additional funds from Algeria -- from the Algerian settlement -- much as we did this year.
The only thing I'd add to that, Dave, is we're an exploration company. You can expect that we'll continue to be spending, in exploration, the kind of things we've done the last several years.

Whether we can continue to sustain what is an incredible success ratio of 67% to 70% will be a difficult dive, but I think one we're prepared to take. I think our guys do a lot better than most at that, and that we are, at the end of the day, we're an exploration company.

So you should expect we'll probably drill somewhere in the neighborhood of another 25 deepwater wells again this year, and we'll balance that with some good predictable, repeatable results onshore and in the Gulf of Mexico to give you the kind of things that we've expected to achieve with the guidance that we gave you back a few years ago, over our five-year horizon, which ends in 2014.
All right. That's all helpful. Thanks. I appreciate it.
You bet. Thank you, Dave.
Your next question comes from the line of Bob Brackett with Bernstein Research. Your line is now open.

Good morning. Question on that 3 billion barrels of reserve target for end of 2014. Should I think of that – there is some moving parts there. One is as gas price rises, you'll kind of rebook some lost reserves. The other is you're just going to go out and spend your F&D and get a certain volume there. And the third is taking kind of lumps of reserves off of, say, an FID or a gas contract for Mozambique. How should I balance those, in terms of thinking about CapEx for the next two years?
Well, I think sort of the watchword on that is we hope and expect that this year, we'll start to net – or plateau, rather -- our net spend. And continue to grow the gross spend.

I look at Lucius, and I'd like to see us do more of that. I think we've got a good shot at doing that with Heidelberg. Bob Daniels does a good job of using third-party money on the exploration to reduce our dry-hole exposure. And yet gives us a lot of swings at the bat.
So from a reserve perspective, we're going to continue to spend at about the level we anticipate this year, and continue to do enough to be able to get to that point of getting to 3 billion barrels.

Now, Mozambique will be a fairly significant contributor to that for the first time post-FID, and maybe what we should do is give a few other people a chance to give you some more color on that. So let me have Bob Gwin talk a little about it, from what he sees in his model, and then maybe Doug Lawler can talk about it, from what we see in Mozambique specifically, since that's the largest contributor.

Yeah, I mean, it's essentially more of the same across the portfolio where, from a reserves bookings standpoint, we're doing very well in the Wattenberg Field. Obviously with the growth rate we've got there, the economics are robust. Eagle Ford is obviously a very large contributor.

Across the onshore U.S. portfolio, we've been in a very good position to continue book reserves. Those reserves continue to be liquids-related. We talked about the aggregate this year driving up in liquids from 43% to 46%.

As we look to the Gulf of Mexico, that's a little lumpier, but obviously, we've had a long history there. And with the exploration projects that we have in place and the future sanctioning of a place like Heidelberg following up on Lucius, we will be booking oil reserves.

And then Mozambique is going to be oil index and very significant, but that's obviously going to be a significant lump in 2014. That will be proved undeveloped, obviously. And most of the rest of what I've been talking about is focused highly on proved developed, as our PUD percentage continues to fall, and we think we take a relatively conservative approach on our offsets and our shale bookings.

Shale bookings have doubled relative to the portfolio here in the last year, but they are still a very small percentage overall. So there's a pipeline of bookings there that we think is pretty substantial, and even well beyond 2014, as we continue to bring additional trains on in Mozambique and execute to plan around the world.
Okay. And you'll book – you'll book Mozambique -- if you have X volume of gas contracts, you'll book X/3 post-FID? Or X/2? Or X/4? How do you think about that?
Well, we haven't provided that type of detail yet.

I think the key there to note to is that the appraisal activity has given us considerable confidence in our reserve resource potential in Mozambique. And we're proceeding with reserve certification. We expect to have that complete in Prosperidad and the Golfinho Atum complex this year. That's an important element as we proceed towards FID, along with several other issues there that need to be addressed with respect to marketing and how we progress that development.

So I think that what you can expect is that -- from your question, there will be -- all of those sources will contribute. And with respect to Mozambique, we're on track and encouraged by what we're seeing there from the appraisal, and hopeful to have reserve certification very quickly.

Great. And then a quick -- crude by rail. It looks like you're moving some volumes out of Wattenberg by rail? Any color there? Is it third-party rail? Is it something you're interested in doing more of?

Bob, this is Chuck. It is third-party rail. And the reason we're doing is, of course, to expand our market exposure and put upward prices on our realizations, in addition to just the local markets and the White Cliffs environment that we have now.
And is that stuff ending up at St. James or something like that?
It can, yes.
Okay, thank you.
Thank you, Bob.
Your next question comes from the line of Evan Calio with Morgan Stanley. Your line is now open.
Hey, good morning, guys. I just have a follow-up on a prior question on rail. With the 20,000 contracted in 2013, does that satisfy your takeaway capacity in each year?

For 2013, you mentioned a rail realization uplift, which is interesting to me. And then question whether you think about rail asset infrastructure investment as a consideration, given your ability to sell that into your MLP?

Yeah, Evan, this is Chuck again. The 20,000 does cover our 2013 and 2014 expectations for production, in addition to what we anticipate selling locally and into the White Cliffs Pipeline. So we're working every element to make sure that we have the ability to export all our crude, and we're pacing our development along with those infrastructure additions.

The rationale, as I mentioned earlier, is to get us broader exposure, not just to Cushing, but to other -- even potentially water-borne markets. So all that is to keep the market competitive with regard to this gigantic new source of crude volumes.

Got it. And I know you mentioned in your operations report, you tested seven wells in the Utica but -- and no real color there. Any color there or what kind of guidance of how many rigs you are running in 2013? And when we might get a better understanding here of the resource? Thanks.

Evan, as we mentioned I believe on the last call, we're testing those wells now. There is – we're just getting the information we need to make decisions on how we progress. We will give you better color as we get some additional production information.
Most of them came online in the last quarter of 2012, so still early days. And you'll hear more about our Utica views as the year progresses.
Okay. I'll leave it there. Thanks.
Your next question comes from line of Brian Lively with Tudor Pickering Holt. Your line is now open.

Hi, good morning. Question from me on the Eagle Ford. If you look at the peak volumes of 54,000 barrels a day versus the Q4 average of, say, 39,000, what were the drivers of that delta? I'm sure some of it was just bringing a bunch of wells on at one point in time, but it seems like still a pretty big delta.

Brian, I think what you ought to read into the peak number is the capacity for us to -- our capacity to sell volumes. And the Eagle Ford, like many of these other large resource plays, continually have constraints in them with regard to new plants being tied in, pipelines going down for expansion, those type of things.

So what we find is – and it's particularly true in the Eagle Ford -- what we find is that our ability to sell our total flow volumes are oftentimes restricted. And every now and then, the stars and moons line up, and we can sell at full volume. And that's when you see the peaks.
All that congestion that we see in the Eagle Ford is slowly getting worked out. And then growing pains, if you will, are slowly dissipating.

Our big opportunity is coming up in the second quarter of 2013 with the Brasada plant. When we get Brasada and its export facilities in place, it opens whole new avenues for crude and condensate and gas to be evacuated from our Eagle Ford. And our uptime as it relates to our capacity will improve, and you'll see really nice gains in our production volumes.
So if I understand correctly, when that plant comes on, you'll see sort of a step-up inflection point, in terms of your sales getting closer to what these sort of daily task numbers are?
Yes.

Okay. And then I think your comments before were on the Utica, but on the Marcellus, I mean the production uplift was pretty strong given the activity levels. What are the sort of leading-edge EURs right now for that Northeast section that you guys are drilling?

Right. Well across Lycoming and Bradford counties and then down into Sullivan County, you're just seeing incredible wells. The economics are strong. It still has a good investment thesis for Anadarko.
The EURs continue to deliver really good economics. We're seeing wells with over 8 BCF type EURs.

And as importantly, in the investment decision, we're seeing our costs come down. And we're down probably in the order of $2 million per well over just a couple of years ago. And that, in combination with the gas flow rates that we're seeing, is 6 million, 8 million, 10 million a day per well, depending upon where you are in the sweet spot. Good EURs and outstanding capital efficiency. We're getting good returns.
I think you'll see the Marcellus continue to grow. There is a bunch of infrastructure projects for evacuation up there. So all that combined makes it a really good opportunity for us.

And just last from me, a follow-up on that. Similar to the discussion on the Eagle Ford, do you guys have a bunch of pent-up production that's just ready for infrastructure? So you talk about the bottleneck is getting better, but is there actual shut-in or curtailed production at this point?
Not really. It's – the pace of completions up there have been such that we are able to sell a good share of our volumes. We haven't had the percent down time, if you will.

There are a number of drilled but not completed wells that are still out there, that we're slowly working off that inventory. So that gives you a little bit of pent-up opportunity, but it's not fallow capital with regard that you have it behind a choke and you can't sell it.
Appreciate the comments. Thank you.
Your next question comes from the line of David Kistler from Simmons & Company. Your line is now open.

Good morning, guys. Switching over to the Wattenberg for a little bit. With the number of wells that you guys drilled, identifying both the Niobrara and the Codell, can you talk about if you're seeing any deviations in those results? And what you're seeing as far as results from the extended laterals and down-spacing efforts there?

So, Dave, this is Chuck again. We're – first of all, we're thrilled with the results at Wattenberg. The production continues to climb, and hope you saw where we produced over 103,000 barrels a day for the quarter. And the liquids is up 17% just quarter-over-quarter. So the thing is just humming along.

And we're doing a lot of spacing tests – the industry is doing quite a bit of spacing tests as well as lateral length tests. And what we're slowly pulling into is around 12 wells per section. Now, there will be sections that will have more than 12 wells per section, probably defining about two-thirds Niobrara, a third Codell. We've really pushed the limits on lateral length out to 9,000 feet and 10,000 feet.

We do see better results with the longer wells – the first few longer wells that we've drilled. It comes at a – with the longer laterals, you have more kit, more completions to do. So there is a timing element involved. And so we're looking at the optimization of the economics on cost versus lateral length.

The good news is that, if you look at the performance, it's really starting to tighten up. And we're getting better and better at getting these wells activated online, down line. The infrastructure is there. The EURs are starting to consolidate around this 350-plus-thousand equivalent barrels a day – I'm sorry – 350,000 barrels for the wells, at about 5,000 or 6,000 foot lateral lengths.

So it's just turned into an outstanding investment opportunity for us. We've essentially done away with our vertical program in the field, and gone strictly to horizontals. And everything we're doing right now is to find the constraining parameter, and then work through it, so that we can accelerate value delivery from Wattenberg.

Appreciate that. And then maybe diving into the cost on that a little bit. In your operations report, you highlighted that on a per-well basis, you're saving an incremental of $0.25 million, as a result of tying in the water trunk line. Can you talk about what average well costs are there now with that kind of a downtick in the well cost?
Well, we just – we have – first off, I'd like to call out our drilling group and just congratulate them on the outstanding performance they've had out in Wattenberg.

We continue to learn. We reduced our spud-to-rig-release time about 38% year-over-year, and our drilling costs are down about 15%. So we're always fighting inflation in oilfield-service costs and trying to outpace those with efficiencies.
One of those is the water-on-demand process that we have now, where we can deliver water to our rigs – to our completions through pipelines and aquifers, so that we have very low-cost delivery.

Before we had to put a bunch of frac tanks on location, do a lot of trucking to get water to those completions. So we've done away with that cost. We've also done away with that footprint where there is not near as many trucks on the road. So it's a very environmentally friendly type of process that we're undertaking.

And our goal is to put these Wattenberg wells online with a four handle right now. And we're running between $4 million and $5 million on each one of them, and we want the average to be on the lower end of that.

These markets move around quite a bit. We've seen this in the past. We're hopeful that the ethane markets will improve, but until they do, we're fine with selling it as gas.
In these liquid-rich projects, we still get the value uplift from our propane, butanes, and so forth. So the economics are still there. And we'll deal with the ethane markets.

But I think some folks think it's an infrastructure issue. It'll be resolved by a plan. It's really not. It's just – it's markets. And we continue to recover ethane, mostly in our Southern region, and reject it in Northern, just because of economics.

And Dave, if I could, it might be helpful if we had Scott Moore, who handles marketing for us, talk a little bit, if you would like us to – our view – we do have a constructive view on ethane longer-term. So maybe I should turn it over to Scott.

Yeah, I think the key point that Al mentioned is that we're well-situated for long-term growth in natural-gas-liquids demand. Great, thanks. My follow up, if I could jump back to the Gulf of Mexico again, to Lucius and I guess the Phobos outlook. You drilled the Spartacus unsuccessful well, and of course, Lucius now looks to be substantially better. Can you help us join the dots as to what didn't work at Spartacus and what the read-through from Lucius could be to Phobos in terms of different horizons, different targets, and so on?
Yeah, Doug, it's Bob. On Spartacus, the (44:24) is separated from Lucius to the north and east. And we have a seismic amplitude there that lined up with a fault-bounded closure.

And we didn't trap hydrocarbons there, so the seismic amplitude that we thought may be associated with hydrocarbons was not. And we have a leaky fault there, so we didn't actually trap any hydrocarbons in it.

If you get down to Phobos, we're looking out a four-way structure, both at the Plio-Pleistocene and at the lower tertiary level. Relatively un-faulted – in fact, not faulted in the Plio-Pleistocene. A few minor pulps in the lower tertiary, but nothing that penetrates on up.
So they are very different play styles between Spartacus and Phobos.

The difference between Phobos and the Lucius complex is there, you've got major faults that radiate out from the Wilcox, all the way up through the Plio-Pleistocene. And we think there the hydrocarbons that were originally migrated into the lower tertiary have leaked and have been trapped immediately in the subsalt section, which will be the Pliocene. And that's what sets up Hadrian and Lucius.

To get that same sort of accumulation of Phobos you're going to have to take the hydrocarbons from Hadrian through a syncline and then back up into the four-way at Lucius, and that's what we are testing in the Plio-Pleistocene. Of course, the unfaulted lower tertiary Wilcox sets up nicely, given that we think that Lucius was breached, and this one does not look like it should have the same breach capacity.
All right, that's terrific Bob. I appreciate the full explanation.
